The remarkable thing is hours worked growth accelerated between Q2 and Q3 given the headwinds in tech, housing, financial conditions, etc. And at the same time wage growth is slowing despite U3 hitting a record low again.

Annualized growth, Q1-Q3 2022:

Jobs (establishment survey): +4.4%, +2.8%, +3.0%
Aggregate weekly hours: +2.9%, +2.2%, +2.9%
Average hourly earnings: +4.8%, +4.6%, +4.4%

@TheStalwart Worker incomes are clearly going to decelerate sub-6% over the next 3-6 months. Everything else seems to be normalizing. Housing's obviously in a weird place right now. We don't need any kind of macro miracle, just more of the same.
@TheStalwart We know now that the wage growth of summer 2021 wasn't a function of a traditional Phillips curve-type relationship, and I'm skeptical that those economists have the right framework.
@TheStalwart I think we should root for a resilient labor market while supply chain/wage growth/inflation data slowly gets back into the zone of what we want. Things breaking is bad.

Leisure wage growth keeps decelerating. The short-term annualized data is looking more like 3-4%, fully normalized: https://t.co/pNtGp0gZPK

If you want the Fed to back off *now* the data lately has been disappointing, but lots of signs that things are evolving in a way that will get us to where we want to be by mid-2023 or so. https://t.co/PfY8IAx9XS
I know that markets are anxious to see labor market softening to get the Fed to back off but every month the labor market stays resilient buys more time for supply chain/inflation normalization.

Over the past year the unemployment rate has fallen from 4.7% to 3.5% while wage growth continues to decelerate. Fair to debate what level of wage growth we’ll settle out at — more likely to be 4% than 3% — but worth pointing out the dynamics of what we’ve gotten.

Last 7 months of aggregate weekly payrolls growth, annualized (pre-pandemic was 5%ish):

Mar: +6.6%
Apr: +7.3%
May: +8.0%
Jun: +5.0%
Jul: +10.2%
Aug: +6.4%
Sep: +6.4%

Modest downshifting from here, which we'll get one way or another, should get us into the zone.

@NathanTankus Joe and Tracy have spent the better part of 2 years doing episodes on supply chains and YIMBY’s think you can change a few laws and we’ll magically get a construction boom.

The YIMBY argument is that with fewer restrictions on development you’ll unlock spare construction capacity or market forces will respond in a meaningful way, but those are lazy assumptions that need a lot more investigation than we’ve gotten.

Since the May CPI report gasoline prices are down, mortgage rates are down, credit spreads tightened, and stocks went up. Real-world financial conditions loosened. https://t.co/GtZOc3YyqH

Ex ante it was unknowable, but by going 75bps in June they crushed commodities speculation (cheaper gasoline!), and shocked the stock market and housing activity down in such a way that by late July a modest recovery starts to look like a bottom. Policy is hard.

When the Fed had everything moving in its direction — short and long-term rates going up, credit spreads wider, stocks lower, housing slower, no pivot in sight — it had the wind at its back. But now some trends have exhausted/potentially reversed. It’s not early-mid June anymore.

@MarcGoldwein You lost the political argument — that happens sometimes.

But “OER is accelerating, therefore core inflation is accelerating and/or household inflation expectations risk becoming unanchored” at a time when market rents are decelerating, commodities have corrected, and private sector signals say the same shows flaws in academic thinking.

Where I think theory added the most value in the inflation conversation was when the size of the American Rescue Plan was announced, where you could compare that package to an estimate of the output gap and project higher inflation than we were used to.

If policymakers are going to use “realized inflation” to make forward-looking monetary policy we really should have an inflation index that uses market rents rather than OER. I just cringe seeing even people like Furman talk about rent accelerating.
